reviewText: As many have said, this is not a traditional Pac-Man game, but it's own beast that borrows Pac-Man mechanics. It still captures the Pac-Man feel perfectly, and on top of that it's the first Pac-Man game I've enjoyed.\n\nThis game seems to be titled Championship Edition" as it turns an endless Pac-Man gauntlet into a 5 (or 10) minute score attack challenge
date: an excellent timeframe for a competition. When played for casual survival
recommended: the game is an absolute breeze that'll bore most fans within hours as you get multiple raw surival mechanisms (bombs and slowdown before collisions) which drastically lower the difficulty of the game.\n\nThe challenge comes from playing for score. Using either of those survival mechanisms or dying will drastically lower your potential final score
hoursPlayed: as after using a bomb you're not able to gather up ghosts to chain for a few moments afterwards. Dying or bombing lowers the game's speed level along with lowering the point value of the dots
voteText: which means you absorb fewer points over time than you would if you had not messed up. It's still better to bomb than to die
helpfulPercent: though - death will shave at least 5 seconds of point-collecting time away.\n\nGhost chaining feels both fun and rewarding - mowing down a massive line of ghosts and watching your score skyrocket is a highly satisfying experience. The longer you play
votesHelpful: the more familiar you become with all the mazes (and how they change over time!) and you amass more and more ghosts into your gluttonous point farm.\n\nThere are online leaderboards where you can view and compete with your friends scores along with automatic replays so you can view their runs
votesTotal: but the global overall ranking boards are currently plagued with blatant cheating (2 bil points? har) that may be a turnoff.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: it's an excellent score attack game. It has an arcade feel to it in that it's easy to get the hang of it
commentsCount: but challenging to master. All things considered
column16: the chaining system feels more fun and rewarding than most arcade shooting games

reviewText:
An absolutely fantastic arcade-style, but with a twist, PAC-MAN game!

+ Uniquely different from what you think when you think 'PAC-MAN'
+ Very difficult and fast-paced
+ Appropriate difficulty balanced: Easy is fairly easy (but not too much), Normal is what I would expect most to play, and Expert is balls-out fast
+ Beautiful visual style
+ Jammin' music
+ A LOT of replayability, and immensely fun to speedrun

- Unlocking the Classic type visuals is a pain. Don't make Facebook sharing a requirement.
- As expected, a lot of the top times in the levels are cheated.

A fair warning, if you plan on tying or beating any individual level runs of this game, good luck, hope you have frame-perfect reflexes all the time. Shoutouts to Nahucirujano, whose runs inspired me to pick up this game. I'm still going to beat Highway II Time Trials though :).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A really fun romp through a surprisingly fast-paced and action-packed Pac-Man system, this game has a lot of potential to be loads of fun for a long time to come.

However, it commits what I believe has become the cardinal sin of video games: requiring social media to unlock things. Players should NEVER have to post to Facebook for an unlock (even in Facebook games, this should be limited to ONCE). Let me say that again, Namco: players should NEVER be required to post to Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, MySpace, LiveJournal, WordPress, or even Steam itself for an unlock in your game. The fact that the ability was even included (and shown off at the end of every bout in the maze) is bad enough, but as an unlock requirement, it's just plain stupid.

Apart from that, the interface could use a little work. It's tough to tell what mode you're about to play in the course if you've unlocked something and have just returned from the Facebook nag screen (note: it's the same mode you just played). It wouldn't be as confusing if the cursor on the menu was in the same place you'd left it (instead, it's on the thing you just unlocked).

So yeah, the social crap is more than a little irksome, especially for a game they aspire to charge money for. However, if you don't mind that (or are willing to put up with it for the sake of a Pac-Man game that looks, sounds, and feels new and exciting), then this game's probably for you.

reviewText: This game is just crazy! I've been playing it for years on my PS3 and am glad to see it on Steam. This ain't yo papa's Pac-Man. It plays differently due to the different modes and the fact that the ghosts are usually lining up in a conga line behind you while others are sleeping, only to awaken when you zoom by. There is also a Speedometer that tells you how fast you are going because the better you do, the faster and faster the game gets. Totally frantic! I have never enjoyed Pac-Man as much as this version.\n\nI picked up the All-You-Can-Eat Edition which includes a lot of DLC. The Dig Dug skin is fantastic! (Rally-X not so much). The new courses are fun. I've seen comments that say Highway II looks just like Highway. It does look the same but it is way harder. There are many wandering ghosts like in the original Pac-Man in addition to the conga line. Mountain is a fun new course. The achievements are few and not that hard to get. If you earn them all and share them on Facebook, you unlock an origianl Pac-Man game skin. Kind of a pain in an otherwise stellar game.

reviewText: As someone who always thought Pac-Man was rather bland, the Championship Edition really mixes things up. There are plenty of different level designs, you can alter the visual style for each map, everything around you changes on the fly, you can be chased by dozens of ghosts at a time. It's intense! Everything is colorful and flashy. The classic arcade sounds maintain nostalgia while the game delivers an enhanced gameplay experience.\n\nThe game has clear objectives as score attack" or "time trials
date:
which is nice because it limits how long you play a single round for. While this lacks an endless mode, it does mean the game is easy to pick to kill short spurts of time with. Power-ups are plentiful enough that you get frequent rewards of vengeance against those nasty ghosts. If you get caught in a jam, one key-press drops a bomb that sends all the ghosts on the board back to their starting point (though these are limited).

Difficulty increases as you progress and a run-in with a ghost knocks your speed down a bit. Naturally, your speed affects score. Scores are recorded to leader boards to compare your scores with friends or the community as a whole.

Pac-Man is a simple game. We all know how it works. Eat the dots. Avoid the ghosts. It's still that same simple, yet addictive gameplay with enough enhancements and flair to take it to a new level of entertainment.

reviewText:
An absolutely fantastic arcade-style, but with a twist, PAC-MAN game!

+ Uniquely different from what you think when you think 'PAC-MAN'
+ Very difficult and fast-paced
+ Appropriate difficulty balanced: Easy is fairly easy (but not too much), Normal is what I would expect most to play, and Expert is balls-out fast
+ Beautiful visual style
+ Jammin' music
+ A LOT of replayability, and immensely fun to speedrun

- Unlocking the Classic type visuals is a pain. Don't make Facebook sharing a requirement.
- As expected, a lot of the top times in the levels are cheated.

A fair warning, if you plan on tying or beating any individual level runs of this game, good luck, hope you have frame-perfect reflexes all the time. Shoutouts to Nahucirujano, whose runs inspired me to pick up this game. I'm still going to beat Highway II Time Trials though :).

reviewText:
The original creator of Pac-Man has seriously modernized the original title, and its hella addictive.

So instead of eating the pac-dots and finishing the maze, you eat dots to spaw fruit, which in turn spawn ghosts for you to train so you can eat them for points.

It's an absolutely minor change, but it seriously makes the game all the more addicting. Time trials, ghost combos, score attack, it's all a blast to play, and theres literally a million tracks to play. The soundtrack is catchy and keeps you on edge as well.

If you thought the original pac man was boring, you might wanna try this. It's insanely dependent on your reflexes, and it's fun as hell.

reviewText:
This edition of Pacman is pretty great [PROs]:
+ Lots of levels to play
+ Lots of play styles [including original pacman style if you complete challenges]
+ Can change appearance, sound and characters you play with
+ You can change the difficulty from being very easy to very tricky
+ Supports keyboards and controllers

reviewText:
Pac-Man CE DX+ is a game of memorization, optimization and micro-optimization, and full-screen awareness. As in traditional Pac-Man games, ghost behavior is deterministic and predictable, so courses can be played entirely on memorized routes - which, due to the incredible speed of the game at Expert levels, is how the game is meant to be played. The game is on a clock, so slowing down is a score penalty.

Finding excellent routes on each board, and executing them, is a lot of fun, but after a certain point, the game loses its replay value. It took around 30 hours for me (across two versions of the game), which isn't too bad, but after hitting S rank on every item, it can be hard to see why to keep playing. There are usually more ways to improve one's score than one might think at first...

Special note to the soundtrack - most of the background music is excellent, especially Pac-Rainbow and Pac-Steps (which is DLC).

reviewText:
An absolutely fantastic arcade-style, but with a twist, PAC-MAN game!

+ Uniquely different from what you think when you think 'PAC-MAN'
+ Very difficult and fast-paced
+ Appropriate difficulty balanced: Easy is fairly easy (but not too much), Normal is what I would expect most to play, and Expert is balls-out fast
+ Beautiful visual style
+ Jammin' music
+ A LOT of replayability, and immensely fun to speedrun

- Unlocking the Classic type visuals is a pain. Don't make Facebook sharing a requirement.
- As expected, a lot of the top times in the levels are cheated.

A fair warning, if you plan on tying or beating any individual level runs of this game, good luck, hope you have frame-perfect reflexes all the time. Shoutouts to Nahucirujano, whose runs inspired me to pick up this game. I'm still going to beat Highway II Time Trials though :).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pac-Man was the first game I EVER played. My parents used to tell me I was only three years old. Of course, I have no idea how true that really is.. but I do have one very old memory of playing the game on the Commodore64.
That being said, it's a true classic. I still love that old game to this very day... but this isn't a review of the original game, is it?

I had to give that brief history lesson, because the sheer amounts of nostalgia I feel while playing this version is almost overwhelming.. yet, at the same time, it also feels amazingly fresh. The first time you gobble down a long string of ghosts, you'll have the biggest grin and probably not even realize it. Why? Because that huge speed increase caught you off guard.. so you'll remember that instead.

The goal is still to get as many points as possible, only now it's done with a time limit. Mazes are divided in two, and clearing one half of dots will place a fruit on the other half. Eating the fruit will cause more dots to appear on the empty half while also altering the maze layout on that half as well.
The dot patterns also often contain green sleeping ghosts. Getting close will wake them and they'll immidiately give chase, becoming rainbow colored in the process (their color constantly shifts and changes). Gathering large strings of these ghosts is a primary method of scoring points when you come across a power pellet.
Blinky, Pinky, Inky, and Clyde are also present and act much like they used to before. Getting too close will also make these guys angry and they can join the train. If so, their eyes will pop back into ghost house to reappear. As such.. Blinky will add quite a bit to the train just because he's the chaser, and the angry ghost train is that on crack anyway. Clyde ends up being a bit dangerous thanks to his somewhat random nature when combined with the train following you and the overall speed of the game. Pinky and Inky are also dangerous in their own regards, just not as much.
<3 Inky

The music also must be stated. Whoever it is who made these tracks deserves more credit than they probably got. There is absolutely no way you'd be able to take your eyes off the action to glance up at a timer at the higher speeds. The closer the timer is to running out, the more intrusive the music gets compared to the sound effects of the game itself.. and it builds up to a climax as the timer runs out. The brilliance behind that cannot go without being mentioned.

This game, man. It's an updated take on a legend, and it's done perfectly. A 'classic' mode would have been icing on the cake.. but whatever. If you're a fan of Pac-Man, you're doing yourself a huge disservice by not AT LEAST trying out the demo.

EDIT Sept. 16, 2015: So having unlocked the 'classic' skin and giving it a go... I feel let down by it, honestly. Keep in mind that Pac-Man is a game I loved since a VERY young age.
But anyway... to nitpick the 'classic' skin if I may, and I certainly may...
..The colors on the sleeping/angry ghosts are horribly muted. I know they didn't exist in the old game, but still. They just look bad. All of the other 'characters' are bright and colorful, but these look drab and boring.
..Inky isn't cyan. For the non-classic skins this is fine. But for the 'classic' skin, why isn't he cyan?
..The ghosts have black eyes. I'm fine with this in regards to the angry ghost chain, but why do the four main ghosts not have blue eyes?
..The normal 'pac-dots' are round. In the original game, circles weren't invented yet. The dots were small squares. In this regard, and for the eye color of the ghosts, the Type A skin does a better job than the classic skin does!

I dunno. The classic skin does some things right, but I just can't get over the nitpicks. It completely fails at being 'classic'. But I can't change my recommendation on that alone.. nobody can. It's still a fantastic game. ...I just won't be using the classic skin all that much. :)

reviewText: Old School Meets New SchoolA classic arcade game walks into an EDM concert. The result? A ravishing assault on the senses: retro soundtracks with a electronic upbeat, multiple visual layouts to keep the playthroughs stimulating, and a new way to play. Rather than a repeat of the same board upon completing it, you have the optional Score Attack where you must earn the highest score before 10 minutes has passed. Every cleared set of Pac-dots boosts Pac-Man's speed, making it more challenging but necessary to obtain a high score even faster.\n\nDon't worry, you can buy yourself time with the newest addition of bombs to return the Ghosts back to the center as well as enter a Matrix moment" to counter a last-minute turn. There are a enough Pac-dot sets that vary by stage and placement and the patterns for them don't repeat too soon either
date: keeping you on your toes. Sadly there are no old intermissions
hoursPlayed: but the new tracks alongside the retro-outfitted one makes up for it! Slow to start

reviewText:
As a player who decides what games to buy based on the reviews of the certain game, it's my duty to write a complete review about any game i finish, so here is my review:

PAC-MAN CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION DX+:

A more-than-a-classic Pac-Man game. Even if it's hard to believe, it has improved graphics and a somewhat different playstyle than the original, while containing the original game itself as an unlockable.

This game brings back the oldschool memories of the arcade Pac-Man game, making it bigger, better, with many more game modes and styles.

Before i procceed with the PROS and CONS i would like to remind anyone who is reading this that these are my personal preferences and may differ by any individual who plays the game.

PROS:
+It's Pac-Man.

CONS:
-Doesn't have a Space Invaders easter egg, as much as i have played

TL;DR A very good game, even your parents will love it.

10/10 waiting for the Space Invaders version

reviewText: This game totally sucked.  JUST KIDDING.  This game is... FANTASTIC. Seriously.  I normally don't review games, but I just felt like I had to, because it was just that awesome.  OK, here's what I was expecting.  Classic Pac-Man, the way I knew it as a kid, but on my PC.  Cool.  Nostalgia time.  Well, I was dead wrong.  Don't get me wrong, it's Pac-Man alright... but radically different.  The game dynamics are vastly improved.  The pellet pattern changes dynamically within the game, making the board feel more like a GAME board than a maze where you simply have to navigate every corner, as it was in the original.  The ghost chases are INSANELY fun.  I had what must have been 50 ghosts chasing me in a row, like the classic snake" game.  And then the it was my turn to eat THEM!!  One after the other in rapid succession
date: down the giant yellow gullet.  There's a "warning" slow down to give you time to react when you're about to be eaten
recommended: but it feels natural and far less frustrating than the original Pac-Man where you hit a ghost and that was it... bloo

reviewText: Wow, is really all I can say. Being a seasoned gamer (25 yrs) I was pretty pleased with what I saw in this game. Although I had not played a Pac-Man game since the arcade classic as a child, and later as a teenager, DX+ was more than what I expected at a glance. Only having spent a minimal amount of time playing I would recommend this game to anyone who loves fast paced puzzle games OR Pac-Man. The course designs and options available for backgrounds are impressive but not over the top. Spoiler - Mine Loader added an alternate score attack mode, and the ability to drop a bomb if you happen to get screwed into a corner-which will happen. Also I liked that they stuck close to their roots here, and gave me some tingly nostalgia. Overall 9/10 (:)) waka waka

reviewText: Got this in the flash sale for £1.99, and it was totally worth it. If you're into fast paced arcade games, or love traditional Pac-Man games and are looking for something a bit different, then this is definitely the game for you. The addition of worldwide leaderboards is a great touch, as it gives you a goal to work towards, and the music and visuals really add to the feel of the game. Also, this game is really easy to get in to, meaning you can easily use it to kill a spare 10 minutes, but immersive enough to spend an hour or two playing. For a couple of pounds, this game is definitely worth a buy.

I don't know how to describe my love for this game.. Especially how it has so many different varieties of Pac-Man's and many different visuals! This game is definitely worth your time, and money! reviewText:
7.25/10 (Good one-time play; little to stay for)
What can I say? This is Pac-Man. True to the original game but with updated, numerous visuals. The persistent increase in speed properly increased difficulty through play. Eating a large train of ghosts feels satisfying, but does end up as too much of a serving of free, easy points. However, after about 2 hours of gameplay, you have already seen all there really is to the game. It doesn't offer much more than competiting against global scoreboards (which, typically, are led by hackers with unrealistic scores).
The gameplay remains rather static in that you are more likely to maneuver yourself into building your ghost train, while avoiding the few ghosts that do chase you in original pac-man fashion. Time attack is enjoyable for the first few times, but once you get used to the modes, there is very little to stay around for.  I feel maze design could have been played with more. Maybe making left and right or top and bottome areas split from each other with the side tunnels used to connect them. Another mode could have been to create as long a train of ghosts as possible.
The game is wel put together, but the need to integrate facebook into it feels forced.

I played this during a free weekend and after two hours, I felt I had played out the game. I finished almost all the achievements too quickly. None of the achievements made me want to push harder.

It was fun for the little time I spent, but I know there is nothing more to keep me interested.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the classic Pacman, if you miss the old arcades, if you wanted to re-live those low-res moments.. this is NOT it!
If you're after a fast arcade flashy-borderline-epileptical experience, then go for it!
It's a polished game with impressive visuals and good use of the limited sounds of the original which have been enhanced" and modernized for the newer audience. The techno-style music gets annoying after a while.
BUT
recommended: it is not THE Pacman.. They should've called it Re-Pacman since the visuals are vastly different and you cannot play the original version. If you want to play the original your only option is to buy the namco museum which is really milking the cow till it's dry.. How hard would it be to include it here and not make us pay yet another time for a 30 year old game..\nSo It's a fun game game for a while

reviewText: This game is a great modern" take on the Pac-Man formula.  The visuals and sound are great
date: and the stages/visual styles are varied enough to keep the game interesting over time.  The actual gameplay is fairly solid but the bullet time mechanic seemed a little bit ridiculous.  It's a useful mechanic when you start playing and helps you get used to the speed of the game... but when you're pretty far up there in game speed it seems like it keeps the game's difficulty down too much.  This is especially clear when you combine the bullet time with the bomb mechanic.\n\nThe major complaint about the game is the UI (seriously
recommended: it's so bad) and the lack of visual settings control.  A game being locked to 720p is really
hoursPlayed: really bad.\n\nOverall a pretty solid title though.  Definitely worth picking up on sale and screwing around with every once in awhile.  Pac-Man Championship Edition DX+ is great for what it is."

reviewText:
Having successfully introduced these exciting new twists to the formula, Pac-Man Championship Edition DX goes one step further by adding enticing new modes designed specifically to ensure that you won't be doing anything constructive for the next few weeks. As well as the usual five- and 10-minute score attacks for each maze, you now get time trials which challenge you to eat a designated number of apples in the shortest possible time. As usual, clearing the dots on one half of the maze presents you with fruit on the other side, so carving the most efficient route becomes an obsession.

reviewText:
PAC-MAN Championship Edition DX+ is a fine game with that is a well-done update on the classic title. The leaderboards and simple-yet-intuitive controls are great.

With that being said - I don't like how simple this game, and the original game, is. When the original debuted around 1980, it was a major breakthrough - I get that. It was the first arcade game that I and many others played. To me, it was 'meh' then and is less-so now. Compared to modern games, it is overly simple and, really, not that fun after about a half an hour. Thats my opinon.

I will vote this game 'yes' under the caveat that you already know you like running around the maze and want an updated version of the game. If you are looking for more complexity than the original - look elsewhere.

I don't enjoy this game, but it is well done considering I understand and have played the original.

reviewText:
It's a bit of a trip compared to the original arcade game but man... I bought the all All You Can Eat Edition and had Dig Dug theme building up for 10 minutes in score attack. Marvellous!

For those older gamers who used to play the original coin-op version of Pac-Man, this version has a few mechanics that might reinvigorate that old spark. You'll probably see from the Store page video the differences, but my favourite is ghost training for that super high score!

As of writing this I've only played 2.2 hours, but I can guarantee I'll get a few mates to toss the controller/keyboard around and see who can top the high scores!

Definitely recommend! :D

reviewText:
Can Pacman still stay relevent at over 40 years old?

───▄████▄─────
──███▄█▀──────
─▐████──█──█──
──█████▄──────
───▀████▀─────

The game starts off simply enough. Its Pac-Man so you are probably familiar with the concept; eat pills and avoid ghosts.

Only now all the 40yr old ghosts are elderly and asleep. You can wake them up though, Metal Gear Solid style.
Wander too close to a ghost whom are scattered around the maze and he will wake up and chase you.
But the games pacing is so slow that you really have to go out of your way to do that.
Infact your mind begins to wander because the game is lit up like a Las Vegas strip with the music having a hard techno beat and yet everything is so slow and easy; I feel like I'm watching a 40yr old stripper and I am just throwing her money out of pity at this point, yeah it's Pac-Man but can it really keep up with the games of today?

The answer is yes, yes he can.

──▒▒▒▒▒──
─▒─▄▒─▄▒─
─▒▒▒▒▒▒▒─
─▒▒▒▒▒▒▒─
─▒─▒─▒─▒─

All that slow pacing and sleeping ghosts is just to ease you into the game, to decieve you into thinking the game is easier than it is.
The light show? Soon that will become trippy and a hinderance as you try to get a good view of the maze to plot your path out in advance! The game speed? It starts to crank up in tune to the music and the music of choice is techno so you know that isn't going to end well, for you! And the sleeping ghosts dotted about the maze? Harmless enough right? Until they are sleeping RIGHT IN YOUR PATHWAY and the original ghosts? They turn up just as the games speed gets cranked right up! Suddenly you realize that this game is out for blood. And you will love it!

Everything is just so, right! The game goes into slow motion if you get too close to a ghost so you can still claw back victory but it returns right back to breakneck speed as soon as you hit safety so you can end up building your own death trap out of panic. You get bombs now which help clear the way of ghosts, a simple concept but one that works and the ghosts? The A.I. is up! Pac-Man A.I. was always a treat even back in 1981 but for a simple game, the 4 main ghosts really had personality to how they chased you or wandered the maze. Now however you can have upto 30 ghosts on screen, maybe more, I lost count! It becomes a snake train of ghosts hunting you down while the original cast of ghosts are not upstaged because they retain their A.I. and the new generic ghosts simply congo line behind you. A touch that I really apprechiate, very nicely done.
Ghosts can now also contain power pills inside of them and eating an additional power pill will extend the timer of its effect, which is also nicely displayed for you to see. This means you actively want a congo line of regular ghosts so you can eat a power pill and wipe them all out for massive points!

The controls are fine, it's Pac-Man, you would have to intentionally go out of your way to break the controls in a game that originally didn't even need buttons. A new visual effect is added that can cause sparks to fly if you are holding down a direction with a wall on it. This needs a bit of explination but in the original pacman, it was common to hold left while a left exit was coming up so you could take the left ASAP, sparks now give a visual indication that you are holding in a direction which given this games amazing speed, is extremely helpful.

──▒▒▒▒▒────▄████▄─────
─▒─▄▒─▄▒──███▄█▀──────
─▒▒▒▒▒▒▒─▐████──█──█──
─▒▒▒▒▒▒▒──█████▄──────
─▒─▒─▒─▒───▀████▀─────

Overall Pac-Man has been in many games since his original introduction. Some where good, some were bad and this is not the first Pac-Man Championship game either. The efforts made to make this game feel like an arcade game but also to feel relevent in the modern era have all paid off.
The game is fun to play and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Some classic games age better than others.

Pac-Man is one of those titles that still plays well today despite the fact it originally came out in 1980. That doesn't mean that it's perfect, however, nor does it mean that people have been happy to leave it alone since that time. Indeed, the Wikipedia entry listing all the Pac-Man games throughout history includes no fewer than 51 games (not including compilations) that either focus on or feature Pac-Man and/or his family at one point or another -- though many of these games radically deviated from the original formula of eating all the dots in a maze while avoiding the unwanted attentions of four ghosts.

Of all the adaptations that remain at least reasonably true to the original game, two of the finest are surely 2007's Pac-Man Championship Edition, which made the game a timed score-attack affair, and its 2010 follow-up Pac-Man Championship Edition DX.

Om nom nom. Or something.
Pac-Man Championship Edition DX (hereafter Pac-Man CE DX) was a masterclass in how to modernize an arcade classic: it kept the original gameplay intact while simultaneously incorporating features that simply wouldn't have been possible on the hardware of 1980. Its biggest change to the formula was the addition of sleeping" ghosts scattered around the ever-changing maze layouts; passing close by them would cause them to wake up and start following Pac-Man in an ever-lengthening rainbow-colored trail. Scoring highly in Pac-Man CE DX was a matter of deliberately building up this trail to be as long as possible
date: then unleashing a Power Pellet to gobble up as many as you could in rapid succession
recommended: the screen exploding in a shower of disembodied ghost eyes flying off the screen as Pac-Man chomped his way to victory.\n\nThe simple addition of the sleeping ghosts had a huge impact on the way you had to play Pac-Man CE DX. Because they were always in the same
voteText: it became possible to calculate an "optimum" route through the game's maze layouts
helpfulPercent: though actually successfully executing that optimum route became more and more difficult as the game accelerated to speeds '80s arcade game makers could only dream of. Fortunately
votesHelpful: the game provides a number of "time attack" modes which prioritize quickly completing mazes over scoring as many points as possible
votesTotal: and these provide a helpful means of learning the layouts a little at a time before applying them to the 5- or 10-minute score attack modes that provide the game's main
commentsCount: you can use the "Ghost Combo" mode to test how many ghosts you can successfully chomp in one go before a Power Pellet's effects wear off.\n\nIf you played Pac-Man CE DX back in 2010
column18: and you're probably wondering what that little plus sign at the end of the title indicates.\n\nWell
column19: it's not a completely new game
column20: though the "Plus" edition does mark its first appearance on PC platforms via Steam. Rather
column21: the new version -- available as a free update for those who already own it on console -- adds a few extra bits and pieces while keeping the core game experience just as it's always been. Specifically
column22: it adds some social and comparison features to make it a little easier to check out how you're doing compared to your friends
column23: and a new set of "medals" to complement the existing bank of achievements and trophies. The game also now has support for add-on content which can either be purchased separately or acquired via the "All You Can Eat" bundle. Currently available DLC includes four new mazes
column24: three new visual themes (based on Dig-Dug
column25: Rally-X and the upcoming Pac-Man and the Ghostly Adventures) and two new background music tracks
column26:
one of which is the finest piece of Japanese jazz funk/drum and bass I've heard from Namco since Ridge Racer Type-4. Have a listen for yourself.


The new mazes are interesting and worth a look for veterans. The Championship III course is a particular highlight
column27: offering a significantly tougher challenge than any of the other courses in the new content -- I found it hard to even break a million on this one
column28: while I'm comfortably well over 1.5 million on most others. Big Eater offers an entertainingly ghost-heavy (and consequently potentially high-scoring) romp that will probably take a few attempts to get your head around
column29: while Mountain offers a highly technical
column30: asymmetrical course that will likewise require a bit of practice to work out the best route through. The weak link in the new courses is probably Highway II
column31: which is just a little too similar to its predecessor for comfort
column32: though nonetheless features some interesting "wrap-around" layouts that require a keen awareness of how both sides of the maze relate to one another as you gobble your way off one side and chomp back on the other.\n\nOne of the more annoying new features about the update is the ability to share achievements and medals on Facebook. Indeed
column33: three of the available medals are tied directly to how many other things you've shared on Facebook
column34: and in order to unlock the classic Pac-Man skin for the game
column35: you need to share all of your achievements and five medals
column36: making for a total of 17 separate posts cluttering up your Facebook page all in the name of making the game look like its 1980 original self.\n\nThere are three main problems with this: firstly
column37: the medals and achievements are all extremely easy to acquire with the exception of one
column38: meaning they're not really worthy of bragging about; secondly
column39: there's no means of posting the one thing you might genuinely want to share on social media
column40: i.e. your actual score and leaderboard position; thirdly
column42: on both the Xbox 360 and PC versions I could not make the Facebook functionality work at all anyway
column43: making the whole thing somewhat redundant. It feels like a half-hearted
column44: unnecessary and badly implemented attempt to add social gaming features into a game that was already pretty good at encouraging competition between friends and among the community as a whole without shoehorning Facebook into the equation. It doesn't need to be there
column45:
and the fact that it doesn't work properly and thus actually locks people out of game content just adds insult to injury.

The "Classic" skin is locked behind Facebook sharing. Boo!
I can't stay mad
column47: Pac-Man Championship Edition DX+ remains as ludicrously addictive as it was the day it came out back in 2010 -- and the addition of a new Steam version means that a whole new audience can now discover it for the first time. Good integration with Steam's network on the PC version means that you can quickly and easily compare your performance to your Steam friends list right from the game's main menu
column48: though it might have perhaps been nice to see a more direct means of challenging one another. Steam Cloud support also means that you can transfer your progress from one computer to another without having to unlock everything all over again
column49: though the reliability of this was occasionally a little flaky while I was trying it out. I lost progress on one occasion
column50: though it's possible this was more due to the dodgy Internet connection I had at the time than a problem with Steam Cloud or the game itself.\n\nRegardless of a few flaws here and there
column51: Pac-Man Championship Edition DX+ remains the perfect coffee-break game -- you can sit down and play for just five minutes and feel like you've had a rewarding experience
column52: but at the same time if you want to spend several hours perfecting your cornering on the game's wide variety of mazes
column53: you can do that too. It's an enjoyably intense experience by yourself
column54: but if you can recruit a few friends to set up an impromptu league of your own
column55: it becomes one of the most addictive games in the known universe. You have been warned!\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
Pac-Man CE DX (the predecessor to DX+) is a great game. The shocker with DX+ is twofold. One, the DLC stages are as good as the older stages*. Two, the menu update that came with DX+ makes the menus less responsive.

CE DX on the Xbox 360 had simple and responsive menus. The menus are mostly the same in DX+, but the few things that they added slow everything down. There's Facebook sharing. Yuck. Whenever you select one of the special skins (Dig-Dug, Rally X, Pac is Back), everything slows to a crawl for around a second as the game loads the skin data and messes around with your settings.

Apparently Namco won't let you play with Dig-Dug characters on a Pac-Man background, or use the Dig-Dug song for anything but the Dig-Dug skin. It's a very silly restriction, and since the practical effect of the restriction is less responsive menus, Namco and the company who did the port should be ashamed of themselves.

Originally, the files for this game were in an easily moddable format. But then the fun police at Namco or Mine Loader Software had to put a stop to it, lest people create custom skins or levels. Everything is now packed into one not-moddable file. At best, this was done because they didn't want people to buy the base game and then pirate the special skins. At worst, it was because they were scared that people would create new content using their intellectual property. Either way, it's bogus, and very, very sad, since it took extra effort to REMOVE modding support.

The game only runs at 720p, which if it were easier to mod might not be the case. If you use a 360 controller, don't forget to turn on vibration in the settings.

*With the new DLC stages, it seems like they only exist in 5-minute mode. The regular DX (not +) stages can be played for 5 or 10 minutes, and have more unique mazes to cycle through before you see the same maze twice.

Once you actually start playing, DX+ is the most fun you can have with Pac-Man. Pac-Man CE DX+ is a fantastic game with very unfortunate business decisions bogging it down. Yes, you should buy it. It's great. Get the version with all the DLC. It's worth it.

reviewText:
You remember Pac-Man? Well, this it, although with some new ideas and it's still fun to play once in while.

It's not only about clearing the screen anymore, but also about some tactics, because most of the time clearing the pre-set-up-screen won't suffice, that's where the new ideas come in.

Often you need to gather as many fruit as you can, sometimes because it's the main objective to gather x fruit from the left and the right side of the screen, and sometimes just for points.

But the fruit does not just lie around anymore, it spawns when you cleared the respective other half of the screen, so planning with that while being chased on high speeds can prove a challenge, because it's not only your typical four ghosts that chase you either.
There's sleeping ghosts, that wake up once you come near them and others that spawn from the middle once any ghost comes in close range to you, so you will find yourself dragging around a long tail of ghosts most of the time, while some don't just enqueue but rather try to come from another side to get you.

You still can fight back using the power pellets and some ghosts grant you another power pellet when eating them to extend your combo, but eating ghosts always increases your game speed. To slow it again, there are just two ways: die or use a bomb.  Bombs send all ghosts chasing you back to the middle and they - as well as lives are given to you at the beginning of each level and it's up to you how to spend them.

For both time trial and score attack you will want to be playing on a decent game speed though, because it increases the things you can do in a certain amount of time, obviously, although in the classic Pac-Man game going around corners could be difficult - it also does here but they included a mechanic to counter that a little: instead of perfect timing you just need to plan ahead, your input is buffered, so if trying to go right at the next corner, just press right against the wall and Pac-Man will remember to turn right as soon as he can. If the speed gets really high, the usefulness of this feature vanishes of course, so yes, it's making the game easier but only so much.
Also if you're about to get caught, time slows down so you have a final chance to react, but again on higher game speeds there's little difference.

Last thing to mention is the screens change while playing: If you cleared out one - let's say the left side - of the screen and collected the fruit on the othere - right -side, the first - left - side may change the layout of its maze and its contents.

The only thing that's a shame is, that if it wasn't for the free weekend, I wouldn't have given this game its deserved second look.

reviewText: Ignore my playtime, as I've had this for a while on the PS3 and just recently got it for PC.\nThat said, this game is incredible. It takes all of the fast-paced gameplay and heartpounding excitement of the original Pac-Man and effectively ups it to an insane degree. There are a ton of courses each with many ame modes and a lot of replay value if you love going for that high score. Bright neon colors, a fast electronic soundtrack, and gameplay that gets almost ridiculously fast make this revival of one of the best arcade games of all time almost certainly worth picking up.\nMy only complaint would be the inability to play Pac-Man in its vanilla form. Otherwise, this is an excellent re-imagining of Pac-Man for the modern day.

reviewText: 5/10.\n\nWas hoping for something more, but was disappointed. This is the same pacman from 1970, with nothing new to add. You just continually go around a small course and collect fruit and dots while avoiding ghosts and eating them. That's it. This edition adds some new skins for you or the ghost, and gives a few different layouts to the level, but the gameplay and repetitiveness doesn't change. After 1 level you have seen basically all this has to offer. And to charge 10 bucks for a 40 year old game is pretty meh. Oh yeah, there's leaderboards too, if that really matters at all. Buy this game if its 95% off and you are like 55 years old and want to relive playing pacman like you did on your atari. Everyone else, this game just reminds me how far we've come in 40 years and makes me grateful games are more than this these days.

reviewText:
I’m old enough to have played the original Pac-Man when it was called “Puck Man” in Japan. Yes, I lived in Japan in the 1980’s. “Pac Man” has a special place in my heart. “Pac Man  DX” is actually a very respectable and fun gameplay variant on the orginal Pac-Man, has excellent production values, and I would have given it my highest recommendation, but....

... It has (apparently) NO ARCADE MODE! You can only play in short bursts, in “time attack” mode, and that is just not Pac-Man!!! You can play for five minutes, or ten minutes. No “next level,” and no cartoon intermissions. “Pac Man DX” only allows you a small time limit to play, on one level. Once the timer runs out, GAME OVER, no matter how well you were doing!

THAT’S TERRIBLE!

Pac Man (and just about all sequels and variants) is an endurance game; you keep playing until you lose your last life! Get to the next level, get the next “key”, see the next “cinema,”  keep going as long as you can.... that’s Pac-Man!

If you’re a fan of “Pac Man,” then sure, buy this, expecially if it’s on sale, but you’ll probably be disappointed (as I was). It’s a total shame, because this could have been a seriously good Pac-Man game if it had and endurance/arcade mode, especially if they added cartoon intermissions.

reviewText: I avoided buying this for a while, and now that I got a chance at it, I am massively dissapointed.  They've taken the perfection of Championship Edition's regenerating maze time trial concept and actually made it *boring*.  The layouts have clear optimal routes so you always know where to go, you're given screen clearing bombs that have no place in a competition-focused game of this nature, and the game even slows down to allow you to escape death with ease.  Score attack games are fun and competitive regardless of how challenging (or not) they are, but while the previous game managed to perfectly merge Pac-Man's gameplay into this frenetic nonstop arena, this time they've gone too far outside the box.  It's a score attack maze game with only a dead Pac-Man husk strapped on to the side.  Play CE instead.

reviewText: How to destroy a classic

reviewText:
PAC-MAN Championship Edition DX+ is an arcade game based off of the original PAC-MAN arcade game. The game centers around two ideas – speed runs, trying to eat all the pills on a stage as fast as possible, and point runs, where the player tries to score as many points as possible within a 5 or 10 minute timespan. The game differs significantly from the original game in many respects, but is still recognizably related to the original game.

Story

There is no story. This is PAC-MAN!

Gameplay

The game, while recognizably very similar to the original PAC-MAN, is also very distinct from it. There are a number of different mazes (stages) for you to play in, with the completion of time trials and point attacks on earlier mazes necessary to unlock later ones. The gameplay is pretty simple – PAC-MAN moves continuously in the direction he is pointed, and can be turned into side passageways. All passageways are exactly as wide as PAC-MAN and the ghosts, so the levels are a series of paths.
Unlike the original PAC-MAN, the stages in the game are not static. Each half of the maze contains a number of pills; once all of the pills on one side of the maze has been collected, a “fruit”, which can take many different forms (some of which are not fruit) appears on the opposite side of the maze. Once that fruit is collected, the cleared side of the maze shifts to the next pattern in a series. The series of patterns is preset, not random, and there is a path through each pattern which is “optimal”, and this path is continuous between patterns. Thus, at its heart, the game is one of memorization, and most of the mazes have at least one path from the top of the screen to the bottom of the screen, and from one side of the screen to the opposite side of the screen, wrapping around and allowing for swift navigation across the stage.
In addition to the pills, there are two other important features in the mazes. The first is ghosts. These enemies come in two flavors; the first flavor is the wandering ghost. Early on, there aren’t any of these, but as the game progresses these continuously spawn, until eventually there are at least four of them, and possibly an infinite number of them – the maze seems to get increasingly crowded as time goes on. Some of these ghosts carry power pills, and some of them carry bombs, but the vast majority of them carry nothing.
In addition to the wandering ghosts, there are static, sleeping ghosts in each pattern. These ghosts are woken up by passing by them, and will start chasing PAC-MAN around the maze. Unlike the wandering ghosts, these ghosts will form a very long line chasing after PAC-MAN, though the wandering ghosts will oftentimes join the pack and join in the chase. The more of these ghosts are woken up, the longer the line will grow. One touch from either kind of ghost will spell PAC-MAN’s doom, but the game slows itself down if PAC-MAN comes close to touching one.
Power pills are much larger pills which spawn in certain patterns of the maze. These can be collected by moving over them and temporarily give PAC-MAN the ability to eat ghosts, scoring a large number of points and eliminating them. Wandering ghosts will respawn after a short period of time, while the sleeping ghosts (and the woken up ghosts) will simply disappear forever after being eaten. As some of the ghosts themselves carry power pills, eating such ghosts (or eating another static power pill on the map) will reset the time allowed to eat ghosts and score points. The patterns of the map are set up such that the player can do this potentially indefinitely, assuming perfect play, retaining effective invincibility and the ability to eat large numbers of ghosts for points. Some of the patterns require PAC-MAN to eat ghosts.
There are also bombs, which can be activated to clear the map of all woken-up ghosts, as well as of all the wandering ghosts. If this is done, all of the ghosts will be put into the center of the map and slowly escape back out into it, pursuing PAC-MAN once more. Bombs are a last-second desperation measure, but they are very effective.
Should PAC-MAN touch a ghost, a death animation is played, the ghosts are returned to the center of the map as if a bomb had been used, and PAC-MAN respawns where he died. The player has a limited number of lives, though can gain extra lives by scoring enough points.
The game itself has multiple modes, as noted. There are a series of time trials, which are intended to teach the player the patterns of the map and for the player to navigate through a few sets of patterns as fast as possible; the first six for any map are to teach the player the patterns, with a seventh intended to run the player through a full rotation of patterns, and the remaining three intended to run the player through a set of patterns with more ghosts wandering around, making it significantly more difficult. The time limits on these are generally fairly generous, but the player, once they set a top time, will change the maximum time limit on the map to the time they scored.
There is a point scoring mode, where the player must navigate a continuous, looping pattern of mazes with an ever increasing number of wandering ghosts spawning in over the course of the map; the goal in this mode is to score as many points as possible within 5 or 10 minutes. In this mode, it behooves the player to continuously maintain power pill status and eat as many ghosts as possible in order to maximize their point total, all while navigating the mazes and advancing the patterns to keep supplying themselves with fresh sets of pills and ghosts to eat.
Finally, there is a “ghost attack” mode, wherein the player’s only goal is to eat as many ghosts as possible within a single continuous use of a power pill, with ten minutes to do so.

Graphics

The game is actually very attractive; while some of the graphical modes, in particular the retro pixel mode, are a bit harder on the eyes than others, on the whole, the game does a good job of visually representing what is going on.

Final Summary

There is very little wrong with this game, but it is very simple; all it has is the very pure gameplay. The game offers little but different maze setups; as a result, it is very likely that after playing a couple hours of the game, the player will have seen almost everything it has to offer save a few more variations on pre-existing setups.
If it does have a flaw, it is that a player who is unfamiliar with PAC-MAN would be a little bit confused at first. Even still, not knowing the controls, it wouldn’t take very long to pick up.
Still, such a limited game is not worth very much of your money, and if you get the opportunity to play it for a few hours for free, you will have seen everything there is to see.

reviewText:
First, I wanna say that this is one of the greatest games I've ever played. I mean, the retro Pac-Man was great, and this one is EPIC. I'll jsut give you one of those pro-cons list down here:


Pros:
+BEST SOUNDTRACK
+If at first you don't suceed, try again.
+Great level designs
+Do you like chaos? This is the game!
+Over 40 ghosts on screen
+And many more!
Cons:
-The idea of there being 4 unique ghost characters is kind of lost
-You kinda need a Facebook account...
+and that's pretty much it!


Overall, I do reccomend this game, it is a great one and if you ask me if I'd buy it for 10 bucks, I say go for it! But I do reccomend buying all the tracks dlc, because at first you only have 1 or 2 I believe. I give the game a 9.5/10!

reviewText: In a nutshell, this is PAC-MAN on steroids. Visually, it's eye candy and it gives the feeling of being on a modernized dedicated arcade machine. The audio track is perfect and creates a mood of tension even before things get hectic. There are new game mechanics and powerups that add nice twists without corrupting the feel of the game. I usually hate leaderboards because I just don't care how well or badly strangers are doing, but they added the ability to replay other people's runs, which is a great way to learn new tricks. It isn't perfect, however. It doesn't support Logitech controllers, and I mean AT ALL. It's not that the buttons do the wrong thing, they do NOTHING. But even if it did work, they took the lazy road and hard-coded the controller layout, which I don't forgive even in a low-budget indie game. But despite that irritant, I still recommend the game for PAC-MAN enthusiasts.

reviewText:
[I've edited my review completely, changing my recommendation.]

This game.  I've lost countless hours to it on the Xbox 360 version, and when I found out it was coming to PC, I was excited.  I really only ever got my 360 out to play this, and having it on my computer instead would be far more convenient.  Pac-Man CE:DX is the sequel to the first Pac-Man CE, something that, I believe, is still limited to consoles and handhelds.  That game was quite fun, and DX took that and gave it a serious make over, both visually and gameplay wise.

This game captures the arcade feel of Pac-Man quite well, minus the sense of endlessness.  If you’ve missed the Pac-Man boat until now, you play as a yellow circle that eats dots and avoids ghosts in a maze.  Why?  That’s a good question.  But, all of that aside, DX is comprised of a couple maze types, all of which have differing qualities that set them apart.  For instance, one called Spiral" features designs that mimic a spiraling shape
date: and has you constantly looping around.  "Junction
recommended:
as you may expect, has a variety of entrance and exit points that allow you to traverse all across the screen in a matter of seconds.  The big draw of the CE series of Pac-Man, is that once you clear a side of a maze (it's divided in half), a fruit will appear. Once eaten, the other side of the maze morphs into something else.  This goes on and on until time is up.  What DX does that the original CE didn't, is that there's now a train of ghosts that follows you around until you gobble them up.  There are ghosts scattered around the maze, sleeping, and they wake up and join the ghost train once Pac-Man passes.  There are also bombs that reset all the active ghosts on screen to the ghost pen in case you get yourself stuck.  Lastly, some ghosts will be carrying bombs or power pellets, so that when Pac-Man is able to eat them, he’ll collect that power-up.

So, basically, the gameplay is: eat a bunch of dots, gather some ghosts to follow you, get a power pellet and go to town.  The maze patterns eventually repeat, and this goes on until time runs out.
There’s a few different gameplay modes, with the big two being 5-minute and 10-minute runs.  These two modes are what you’ll be coming back to, and they are the core gameplay of doing what I’ve already described in the time limit.  The other modes are:
*Ghost Combo: Eat a power pellet, and consistently eat ghosts for as long as possible.
*Time Trial: Complete the course as fast as possible
*Darkness: Complete the maze when only the dots light up the walls; everything is hard to see
*Free Play: Do what you want in the maze without a time limit

The visual style of this game is fantastic, and is something my friends frequently joke about being something that would be wonderful to watch while under the influence of something.  Namco-Bandai kept the charm of the original game, and then smashed in some dubstep and trippy visuals.  You can also select different visual styles of Pac-Man (from the iconic arcade type, to the design seen in Pac-Mania) and colors for the maze.  Overall, they WILL NOT detract you from the game going on, but people watching may get a bit hypnotized.  (I will note that there are a few visual styles that make things a bit more difficult, but you’ll find what works best on your own.)

The music is hit or miss for me.  Some tracks stand out, others are boring.  The annoying thing about the music in general, however, is that as time runs out, the music reaches a quickened pace to mirror the dread of you're almost out of time
hoursPlayed: better hurry up and get that last bonus."  If you're like me
voteText: this can easily put you on edge and screw up where you normally don't.  I usually just keep the music off and listen to something a little more slow and/or peaceful (it's helped me numerous times when I tried to beat my high scores).\n\nYou can breeze through most of the mazes in an hour or two
helpfulPercent: and you’ll be coming back for more to beat high scores and get on the leaderboards.  It’s important to note that you are paying for a game that you’ll play the same couple levels over and over again

reviewText: Really shouldn't have been called Pac-Man, it's more of a maze/puzzle game time attack. Grab all the dots on one side of the screen, grab a powerup, and that cleared side gets refreshed with a new maze. Each maze has sleeping ghosts you can avoid, or run by them to make an aggro chain of thousands of points. Losing isn't really a thing, as when you almost hit a ghost, the game does slow-mo to let you get out, or use Bombs to wipe ALL the awake ghosts. Of course, when they come back out of the spawn, they can very well cut you off and force you to spend another bomb to reroute the ghost train. It's not very engaging, too focused on flashy visuals and connecting to Facebook. The visuals are surprisingly strong (and annoying) for what is a more-casual Pac-Man. Yes, it gets fast, but the penalties don't exist when you can bomb or give up a life to slow the pace down, or just abuse slow-mo.\n\nI saw about all there is to the game in under 2 hours. Even at 66% off, it still seems high. Yes, there are many maps, but it's the same idea and just too simple to make me return to the game. There is no infinite play or anything like the original, there is no intelligent AI, and the mazes repeat their patterns noticably in just 5 minutes. It takes no time to learn, and just doesn't compel me to master it.

reviewText: It's a pretty cool little game that will find an audience among the casual crowd. I can just imagine people playing these levels over and over again, trying and beat their friends' high scores. I was a little disappointed by the lack of a traditional Pacman mode (meaning only 4 ghosts with only 4 power ups and lots of dots) but the game proved to be addicting nonetheless. With dozens of levels and dozens of modes, pick it up and give it a try if you love Pacman and/or have a strong desire to compete for high scores among your friends.

reviewText:
This game stutters no matter what res I run it at.  And Namco doesn't even acknowledge the issue.  They say it's our rigs, but I would think if that were the case, then dropping it down to 640x480 resolution should have removed the stutter, but nope...and if it really was my rig, that means the recommended specs would have to be higher than Skyrim, Far Cry 3, and other games, since those games run just fine at a resolution of 1600x900 on this 3 year old rig.

Considering it took pretty much everyone complaining to Namco just to even get them to fix the facebook integration (this in spite of the fact you could just fire up the game yourself and see there was an issue), I don't think they have any plans to fix the stutter.

Shame too, as Ms. Pac Man was my first video game I ever played, always been a fan of the Pac Man games.  But I don't recommend this on the basis that the devs are clearly not wanting to put effort into this release.  Lazy port.

reviewText: Not what I was expecting.  I was hoping for a modern version of the classic Pac-Man/Ms. Pac Man.  This game has ghosts, mazes, and dots but its mechanics turn it into a perfection speed reflex game instead of classic Pac.  I hate the interface, its not inuitive, clunky on a keyboard and not very customizable.  This game is  good in its own right, but isn't what I wanted so I can't recommend it.  It looks like electric neon Pac-Man but there isn't enough Pac in the sack.

reviewText:
This game reminds me of TRON.

And that's because I don't have a single CLUE (got it ... ? ... ;) why this has been done to a timeless formula I loved during my childhood.

Please note that my review has nothing to do with the visual style(s) of the game but with the game play mechanics itself and on top of that with the ghost AI.

Actual the visual style(s) - and there is a sh*tload of this in here -  of the game is very appealing featuring many different versions of the game I played back in the days.

The only thing they forgot to implement was the original game ... or maybe you get it after playing through this massive and repeating bulk of bullsh*t ... I don't know ... and I most likely never will ...

I think I prefer the original arcade or playing Pacman96, Bomb Pac, Pacman Deluxe on Amiga (all of them are freeware, shareware or public domain - at least nowadays).

In case I want a twist in the formula I could even play Platman (a very nice platform pacman game) amongst many other that were in most cases also released as freeware for Amiga compatible systems years ago all available through Aminet.

Sorry Namco ...

... if you hate me now for this review ... just call me classic ... ;)

reviewText: So lame. SO much flashing, obstructed views from pointless text overlays just obscure your view, and distract the player. Die from your blocked view, lose track of your Pacman character after re-spawning,  because of the intrusive flashing effects, charcter trail overlays,etc. The menus and interface are constantly seeking confirmations to exit to the LAST menu instead of leaving this f***ing game.You can't even play Pacman with Pacman graphics-you have to play these cheesey mazes to earn the genuine pacman graphics ( but not an original Pacman or Miss Pacman game ) !\nIn the speed trials, if you succeed in setting new record time, it sets the next level at YOUR record time, but at the normal speed, making the next time period to complete  impossible - you are just stuck at that time limitation, without the necessary speed to accomplish the task !\nI just quit in frustration now. Why do they even call it Pacman ? I've wasted too much money on stupid games from Steam. I play less a quarter of them because the interfaces, scrolling, or restricted view of your game field. Pacman DX is just another exercise in Steam frustration. I'd like a refund for this, Company Of Heroes, Chains, Day Of Defeat, Fallout New Vegas, Far Cry 3 ( glorifying drug running), and I'd like to simply remove Tropico3 about running a communist country (a gift) from my games list. Pacman DX? THREE thumbs down ( and I only have 2 thumbs).
